tossups.question: This situation is created when the Zener voltage is reached and current flows to the gate of a thyristor in a crowbar system. The virtual ground assumption is a special case of a virtual one of these situations that occurs because an ideal op amp has infinite open-loop gain. This situation’s equivalent in the hydraulic analogy is the appearance of a (*) hole in a pipe. This situation occurs when an ammeter is connected in parallel instead of in series. Two nodes have no potential difference in this situation. Mismatched loads, overloads, and these situations are protected against using fuses and circuit breakers. Connecting the terminals of a battery will cause, for 10 points, what dangerous situation that occurs when an unintended connection is made in a circuit?
tossups.answer: short circuit [accept word forms such as shorting; accept descriptions of the creation of a connection with no/low impedance/resistance; prompt on answers suggesting redirection of current; prompt on electrical fault; prompt on blowing a fuse, tripping a circuit breaker, current overload, overheating, or electrical fire with "what situation in the circuit is causing that to happen?"]

tossups.question: This man's book on "Economic Sense and Nonsense" popularized the "parable" of the Capitol Hill Babysitting Co-op's demand-led depression. This economist expanded on W.M. Corden in a paper arguing that companies will operate where transportation costs are lowest in the "home market effect," part of his New Economic Geography. Robert P. Murphy co-hosted a podcast where he refuted this author of Arguing with Zombies every week. This man incorporated consumer preferences into a Nobel-winning model on New Trade Theory. He wrote that the US was suffering the effects of a (*) liquidity trap in an analysis of the 2008 financial crisis. For 10 points, name this author of The Conscience of a Liberal, an economist and op-ed columnist for the New York Times.
tossups.answer: Paul Krugman [or Paul Robin Krugman; accept Contra Krugman]

tossups.question: The similarities between this author and Friedrich Nietzsche are explored in an essay by Edward Said, whose first book is titled for this man and "The Fiction of Autobiography." Maya Jasanoff's recent book about this author in the context of globalization analyzes the extractive capitalist Mr. Holroyd who appears in a novel set in the fictional country of Costaguana. This author was criticized for using a certain place as "a foil to (*) Europe" in an essay on the "racism" in one of his books by Chinua Achebe. That book by this author is narrated from a boat on the River Thames and tells of an ivory trader whose final words are "The horror! The horror!" For 10 points, name this author of Nostromo who wrote about Kurtz in Heart of Darkness.
tossups.answer: Joseph Conrad [or Józef Teodor Konrad Korzeniowsk]

tossups.question: This conflict popularized the use of the word "Razakar" for traitor. Teachers and other professionals massacred in the final days of this conflict are remembered on Martyred Intellectuals Day. The US government was made aware of atrocities in this conflict by the Blood Telegram. George Harrison organized the world's first benefit concert to support victims of this conflict. One leader vowed to "kill three million" during Operation (*) Searchlight in this conflict, which was precipitated by the devastating 1970 Bhola cyclone. Sheikh Mujibur Rahman became the first president of a new country following, for 10 points, what war in a region then known as East Pakistan?
tossups.answer: Bangladesh Liberation War [or Bangladesh War of Independence; or Muktijuddho; accept Bangladesh Genocide; accept 1971 East Pakistan Civil War before the end; prompt on Liberation War]

tossups.question: In contemporary stagings of one sequence, this character's partner drags her across the floor, paying homage to the original staging's use of a scarf stunt to make her appear to glide. Despite receiving five curtain calls, Antoinette Dell'Era was originally deemed too fat and ugly to premiere this role by the composer's brother, Modest. Maria Tallchief danced this role in her ex-husband George (*) Balanchine's 1954 production of the ballet in which it appears. Keira Knightley plays this role in a 2018 film in which Misty Copeland dances with Prince Coqueluche ("koh-kay-loosh"). The "Waltz of the Flowers" precedes this character's namesake variation, which features a prominent celesta solo. For 10 points, name this ruler of the Land of Sweets in The Nutcracker.
tossups.answer: the Sugar Plum Fairy [accept "Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy"]

tossups.question: The "brain" variety of these values adjusts the relative sizes of their two main components and are used in deep learning applications that tolerate lower accuracy. William Kahan's error-minimizing algorithm subtracts algebraically-equivalent expressions of these values to get a non-zero value that is added back in. The IEEE ("I-triple-E") 754 standard expresses these values in terms of their (*) significand and defines edge cases like NaN ("nan"). Computing power is typically measured by measuring the number of operations on these values per second, a unit dubbed the flop. The quadruple is an extension of this data type accurate to 128 bits. For 10 points, name this data type which stores approximations of real numbers and is contrasted with ints.
tossups.answer: floats [or floating-point numbers; accept bfloat16s or brain floating point; accept doubles, halfs, or singles; prompt on numbers or decimals]

tossups.question: One of the first exhibits at a newly opened New York museum devoted to works in this medium contains a groundbreaking 1894 work done in gold pastels that depicts its subject as a Byzantine icon. This medium was used by Alphonse Mucha to portray Sarah Bernhardt as Gismonda. A hand grips the neck of a cello in the foreground of a work in this medium that focuses on the (*) dancer Jane Avril. In the bottom-left of another work in this medium, a large 'R' is encircled by the tail of the title animal, Le Chat Noir. Louise Weber frequently appeared in works in this visual medium as the can-can dancer La Goulue ("goe-loo"). For 10 points, name this print medium used by Henri Toulouse-Lautrec to advertise the Moulin Rouge.
tossups.answer: posters [accept theatrical posters or advertisement posters or posters for the Moulin Rouge; prompt on lithography or print]

tossups.question: A character in this novel causes a scene at a party by shouting "Good God! What is the meaning of this?" at a man who her family mistakenly believes is her fiancée after he ignores her letters. That character in this novel later returns the letters along with a lock of hair. This novel's protagonists move to Barton Park after their sister-in-law reduces their (*) inheritance. Characters in this novel include the vulgar Steele sisters and a man who marries Sophia Grey after he is disowned for seducing Eliza Williams. A woman in this novel is spurned by Willoughby, but later marries Colonel Brandon, while her sister marries Edward Ferrars. For 10 points, name this Jane Austen novel where Elinor and Marianne Dashwood represent the two title concepts.
tossups.answer: Sense and Sensibility

tossups.question: After this man's downfall, his supporters were punished by having the "Lady Wailer" bell removed from a tower, put on trial, and then flogged as it was dragged through town. This man lost public support after rain prevented the first trial-by-fire planned for his city in 400 years. Angry mobs made up of the Arrabbiati and Compagnacci fought with supporters of this man called the Frateschi in a clash at (*) San Marco's. This man, who rejected the "red hat" offered to him by Pope Alexander VI, faced off against a hostile Signoria elected in March 1498. A year earlier, his Piagnoni presided over an event where works by Dante and Ovid were destroyed. For 10 points, name this Dominican preacher who ordered Florence's Bonfire of the Vanities.
tossups.answer: Girolamo Savonarola [prompt on Fra Girolamo]

tossups.question: Old Irish homes often have skulls of these creatures placed under the floorboards to improve the acoustics for dancing. In England, "toadmen" used pleasant or foul-smelling odors to control these creatures. One of these creatures from the chansons de geste that could adjust its size at will was known as Bayard. In Welsh myth, after her maids smear dog's (*) blood on her face to frame her for the death of her son, the wife of Pwyll (“pwill”) is effectively forced to live as one of these animals. Medieval readers of the Alexander Romance learned of the taming of one of these creatures named Bucephalus. The mythical queen Rhiannon may be a version of a Celtic goddess of these animals, Epona. For 10 points, name these animals often mounted by knights.
tossups.answer: horses [or steeds; or mares]

tossups.question: Jacques Derrida's commentary on this philosophical text in The Gift of Death introduces his formula that "every other is wholly other." This book notes that a field lacks an equivalent to the old servant who speaks for the silent Agamemnon in the play Iphigenia in Aulis before investigating a merman's seduction of Agnes. This book, published the same day as its author's Repetition, poses three "Problemata," the first of which asks if there is a (*) "teleological suspension of the ethical." The author's relationship with Regine Olsen may have inspired this book's discussion of the "knight of infinite resignation" and "knight of faith." For 10 points, name this philosophical analysis of Abraham's sacrifice of Isaac by Soren Kierkegaard.
tossups.answer: Fear and Trembling [or Frygt og Bæven]

tossups.question: Excessively high or low amounts of this molecule may result in retinopathy in prematurely born babies. Areas with low concentrations of this molecule promote angiogenesis through the action of HIF, a factor said to be "induced" by low amounts of this compound. Facultative organisms change their primary mode of metabolism based on the presence or absence of this molecule. One compound's affinity for this molecule is affected by pH changes in an effect named for Christian (*) Bohr. The presence of this molecule leads to inefficiency in RuBisCO activity as it causes photorespiration. Aerobic and anaerobic respiration occur based respectively on the presence or absence of this molecule. For 10 points, name this diatomic gas carried by hemoglobin.
tossups.answer: oxygen [or O2]

tossups.question: A one-act drama by this author ends with a man's "pitiful howl" of "OH MY GOD!" being mocked by another man, who is dying. In that play by this author, which is often performed alongside this playwright’s Homelife, a man recounts yelling "YES, A BITE FOR MY PUSSYCAT" while buying hamburger meat to poison his landlady's dog. This author referenced A Streetcar Named Desire in a scene in which a man says "Flores para los muertos" while throwing snapdragons. Peter accidentally (*) stabs Jerry while they fight over a bench in a play by this author set in Central Park. Another play by this author ends with Martha answering the title question by saying "I am, George, I am." For 10 points, name this author of The Zoo Story and Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?
tossups.answer: Edward Albee [or Edward Franklin Albee III]

tossups.question: A German-born naturalist on a 1733 expedition sponsored by this country lends his name to the Steller's Jay. This country gained the Coastal Territories through the Supplementary Treaty of Peking in the Second Opium War. Daniel Gottlieb Messerschmidt's 1720s exploration of this modern-day country discovered the first fossil remains of a mammoth. Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz convinced a leader of this country to sponsor an expedition to find a (*) land bridge. A Danish-born explorer helped this country establish a fur-trading colony in North America. This country's control of distant territories improved with the completion in 1912 of a 5,772-mile-long railway. For 10 points, name this country that sold Alaska to the US.
tossups.answer: Russia [or Russian Empire; do not accept the “Soviet Union” as none of the clues apply to that time period] (the Danish explorer was Vitus Bering)

tossups.question: Swiss environmentalist Bruno Manser may have been killed on this island for trying to help its Penan (“peh-NAN”) people fight loggers. A government on this island that practices the MIB ideology uses profits from the BSP oil company to subsidize food and shelter. Abdul Taib Mahmud's government presided over massive deforestation on this island despite opposition from its (*) Dayak people. A 2007 "Heart of [This Island]" agreement protects its 140-million-year-old rainforest. Because a city on another island is sinking, Joko Widodo announced plans to build a new capital on this island, which is divided into regions such as Sarawak. For 10 points, name this large island which is divided between Malaysia, Brunei and Indonesia.
tossups.answer: Borneo [or Pulau Borneo; or Kalimantan]

tossups.question: Anions of these elements can be separated from their cations using amine-only cryptands or other nitrogen-based cage compounds. Electrides are formed from these elements and have a deep blue color from their solvated electrons. Individual examples of these elements can be selectively complexed by crown ethers. The strongly periodic trends of this (*) group of elements reverse in its final member, which is only the second most electropositive. This group of elements is typically stored under mineral oil, as they rapidly cleave water. Cations of this group of elements consistently form soluble salts and always have a charge of +1. For 10 points, name this group of very reactive metallic elements which includes francium and lithium.
tossups.answer: alkali metals [or Group 1 or Group 1A; accept alkalides; accept just 1 or 1A after "group" is read; do not accept or prompt on "alkaline earth metals"]

tossups.question: Dmitri Shostakovich's second work for this ensemble begins with a passage played entirely using string harmonics. Maurice Ravel wrote a passacaglia for the third movement of his A minor work for this ensemble. Tchaikovsky's A minor piece for this ensemble is subtitled, "In memory of a great artist." Sergei Rachmaninoff gave the title "élégiaque" (ay-lay-ZHAHK) to his two pieces for this ensemble, for which Antonín Dvořák's wrote a piece subtitled after the Slavic (*) dumka. Ludwig van Beethoven wrote several pieces for this ensemble such as one that reminded Carl Czerny ("CHAIR-nee") of the ghost of Hamlet's father, and one that was dedicated to Archduke Rudolf of Austria. For 10 points, name this ensemble of violin, cello, and a namesake keyboard instrument.
tossups.answer: piano trio [accept all of piano, violin, and cello in any order; prompt on trio]

tossups.question: In the Book of Genesis, a natural feature called Machpelah is used as one of these places after Abraham purchases it from Ephron the Hittite. In the Gospel of John, Nicodemus brings seventy-five pounds of myrrh and aloes to one of these places. In the Latin Vulgate, a woman mistakes a man for a gardener at one of these places, recognizes him, and is instructed "Noli me tangere," or "touch me not." Jesus proclaims, "Did I not tell you that if you believed you would see the glory of God?" to (*) Martha before a stone covering the entrance to one of these places belonging to Lazarus is removed. For 10 points, what kind of place was found "empty" by Mary Magdalene in the gospel narratives following Jesus's resurrection?
tossups.answer: tombs [or graves or burial grounds; accept cemetery or graveyard; prompt on caves]

tossups.question: Walter O. Evans' extensive collection of papers relating to this man was a key source for David W. Blight's Pulitzer-winning 2018 biography. Rutherford B. Hayes made this man Marshal of the District of Columbia but did not allow him to receive foreign dignitaries. This husband of Helen Pitts declared "I have no patriotism. I cannot have any love for this country" in his "Fifth of July" speech. H.R. 51 proposes turning the (*) District of Columbia into a state named for this man. This most-photographed man of the 19th Century wrote three memoirs, the second of which was titled My Bondage and My Freedom. For 10 points, name this abolitionist publisher of the North Star whose Narrative describes his escape from slavery in Maryland.
tossups.answer: Frederick Douglass [or Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey]

tossups.question: An author who shares her surname with this city wrote a semi-autobiographical story about a woman who steals sleeping pills while working as a cleaning woman. Alec Leamas is recalled from his job running a branch of the Circus in this city in the opening of John le Carré's The Spy Who Came in from the Cold. A long modernist novel about this city's underworld is by Alfred Doblin. Sally Bowles sings in a (*) nightclub in this city in a book by a frequent collaborator of W. H. Auden. Christopher Isherwood's Goodbye to [This City] inspired the musical Cabaret and is set during the final years of the Weimar Republic. For 10 points, name this setting of Anna Funder's novel Stasiland, a collection of stories from behind its namesake wall.
tossups.answer: Berlin [accept Lucia Berlin or Berlin Alexanderplatz or Goodbye to Berlin; accept East Berlin or West Berlin]

tossups.question: Emigrants from this modern-day country were told to choose between "the suitcase or the coffin" in the same year in which hundreds of people were exposed to nuclear radiation in the Béryl (“bear-eel”) Incident. Thousands of foreign nationals fled this country following threats from GIA terrorists and a 1992 coup against the FIS party. Gillo Pontecorvo's film about a battle in this country depicts gruesome torture ordered by General Massu. Raoul Salan organized the (*) OAS to prevent this country's independence a few years after a namesake "crisis" brought down the Fourth Republic. Many pied-noirs ("pyay-nwarr") fled this country following the 1962 Evian Accords. For 10 points, name this North African country which fought for independence in the 1960s from France.
tossups.answer: Algeria [or People's Democratic Republic of Algeria]

bonuses.leadin: This photographer lent his studio for the exhibition of Impression, Sunrise. For 10 points each:
answer: Alexandre Dumas [or Alexandre Dumas père; or Dumas Davy de la Pailleterie]
parts: Name this Frenchman who photographed the Paris Catacombs. An Honore Daumier (oh-no-RAY dome-YAY) cartoon depicts this photographer taking pictures from his hot air balloon, Le Geant.

While visiting this city, Nadar erected crowd control barriers which are now named after him. It’s not in Switzerland, but this capital city's legacy as a chocolate powerhouse comes from companies such as Godiva, which was founded here.
This author and namesake of a Paris Metro station was photographed holding a card by Nadar. This author's novel The Count of Monte Cristo inspired over 20 film adaptations.

bonuses.leadin: Proteins that perform this process typically have either HECT domains or RING domains. For 10 points each:
answer: ubiquitination [or ubiquitinylation; accept any answers indicating a ubiquitin is being attached to a protein]
parts: Name this process performed by E3 ligases, which modify proteins so that proteasomes can later target them for degradation.
The transition to this stage of the cell cycle is pushed along by an E3 ligase known as this phase’s namesake "promoting complex". In this phase, sister chromatids are pulled apart.

The second motion of anaphase is sometimes named for this letter. Metaphase ends and becomes anaphase with the destruction of a cyclin named for this letter, whose concentration peaks after the peak of cyclin A.

bonuses.leadin: In 2018, Sharp was mocked for getting this certification for a refrigerator sold in Indonesia, part of a growing trend for giving this certification to non-edible products. For 10 points each:
answer: halal [prompt on permissible, permitted, lawful, or allowed]
date palm [or Phoenix dactylifera; prompt on palm tree]
parts: Name this Islamic dietary certification. Animals must be slaughtered according to the method of dhabihah (“dah-BEE-hah”) for their meat to receive this certification.
Alcoholic beverages such as khamr are not halal. In Muhammad's time, khamr was often made from this plant whose fruit is the traditional food used to break the Ramadan fast.
The government of this country has used the Covid-19 lockdown to crack down on alcohol sales, banning drinks such as raki in favor of the non-alcoholic ​ayran​.

bonuses.leadin: This process pushes out ions as the forming lattice rejects brine. For 10 points each:
answer: freezing [or freeze desalination; prompt on crystallization]
fouling [accept precipitation fouling, macrofouling, microfouling, or biofouling]
ocean waves [accept wind or gravity waves; accept wave powered desalination or wave energy converters]
parts: Name this phase transition used to desalinate water in particularly cold climates.

First pioneered in the 17th century, freeze desalination is receiving renewed attention because it does not experience this problem, in which undesired material builds up on a surface. Examples of this problem include precipitate scaling and the formation of biofilms.

These phenomena provide onsite renewable energy for several experimental desalination projects. WECs (“W-E-Cs”) move up and down or tilt back and forth to do work as these phenomena pass by and can be used in more places than tidal power plants.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about queer films and film festivals:
answer: Sundance Film Festival [prompt on Utah Film Festival or US Film and Video Festival]
parts: Name this director of Happy Together, a film about a troubled gay couple from Hong Kong who set out to visit the Iguazu Falls. This man also directed In the Mood for Love.
It's Not a Cowboy Movie was the first short film winner of the Queer Palm. It follows French teenagers who watch this 2005 Ang Lee film starring Heath Ledger and Jake Gyllenhaal.

Ball culture documentary Paris Is Burning won the Grand Jury Prize at this film festival, founded by Robert Redford. This Park City, Utah event has launched indie films such as The Blair Witch Project.

bonuses.leadin: The mother of this novel's author sent a letter to editor Robert Gottlieb blaming him for her son's death because he refused to publish this novel. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this novel whose Boethius-reading protagonist Ignatius J. Reilly progresses through a series of menial jobs after his mother gets drunk at the Night of Joy bar and rams her Plymouth into a house.
Reilly ends up selling Paradise Vendors hotdogs from a pushcart around the French Quarter in this city in John Kennedy Toole's A Confederacy of Dunces.
The novel was eventually published when Toole's mother forced this professor and author of The Last Gentleman and The Moviegoer to read the manuscript.

bonuses.leadin: The Aetos Dios was one of these animals, and two of these animals were sent out to determine the center of the earth. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these creatures, one of which Zeus either summoned or transformed into in order to kidnap Ganymede.
According to some sources, this wise centaur replaced Prometheus to be tormented by an eagle, though in other versions, Heracles shot down the eagle to end the torture.

According to Antoninus Liberalis, an autochthonous ("ah-TAHK-thuh-nous") king of Athens, Periphas, was turned into an eagle. The daughters of Cecrops went insane upon seeing this later autochthonous ruler of Athens, who had the lower body of a snake.

bonuses.leadin: On July 23, 1788 the Society of Pewterers carried a gigantic banner in support of this cause for a parade in Poughkeepsie (“pah-KIP-see”), New York. For 10 points each:
answer: ratification of the US Constitution [accept word forms; accept answers like adopting the US Constitution; prompt on Federalism]
The Federalist Papers [or The Federalist: A Collection of Essays, Written in Favour of the New Constitution, as Agreed upon by the Federal Convention, September 17, 1787]
parts: Identify this cause, of which New York delegates approved thanks to a compromise between Alexander Hamilton and a faction led by a moderate anti- named Melancton Smith.
These documents were written in support of ratification by Alexander Hamilton, James Madison, and John Jay.

Richard Henry Lee was long believed to be the anti-federalist writing pseudonymously as a "Federal" one of these people. Pre-revolutionary America was discussed in Letters from an American one of these people, a work by J. Hector St. John de Crèvecœur (“krev-kur”).

bonuses.leadin: This work was inspired by the eclogues of Virgil and Mantuan ("MAN-choo-uhn"). For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 12-part pastoral poem published in 1579 which depicts the life of the title character, Colin Clout, over the course of a year.
The Shepheardes Calender was the first major poetic work of this English poet who also wrote The Faerie Queene.
Spenser dedicated The Shepheardes Calender to this other Elizabethan poet, a fellow member of the Areopagus who wrote the sonnet sequence Astrophel and Stella.

bonuses.leadin: In his book The Transported of KwaNdebele (“kwa-en-da-bee-lee”), photographer David Goldblatt captured people on the punishingly long commutes from these places to their jobsites. For 10 points each:
answer: Bantustan [or Bantu homeland; prompt on black state]
parts: Give this term for the 10 territories designated for Blacks by the South African government. One of these places called Transkei was made "independent" in 1976.
Bantustans were a part of this South African racial system that ended in the 1990s.

Sol Plaatje, who opposed the Natives Land Act of 1913 that restricted the land rights of Blacks, now names a university in this city. This capital of South Africa's Northern Cape province is where Cecil Rhodes made his fortune in diamonds.

bonuses.leadin: The Lancet retracted a 1998 paper it published by this physician because he had falsified data. For 10 points each:
answer: France [or French republic; or République française] (the Nobel winner was Luc Montagnier)
parts: Name this physician who has promoted the incorrect idea that the MMR vaccine causes autism.
In 2010, Wakefield visited a community of Somali-Americans in this state and convinced many of them not to get the MMR vaccine. Ilhan Omar represents a district in this state.

Vaccination rates for Hepatitis B in this country plunged following a documentary about aluminum in the vaccine. Other medical skepticism in this country stems from the thousands of deaths from the diabetes drug Mediator and from a Covid truther who won the 2008 Nobel Prize for HIV research.

bonuses.leadin: This adjective describes pipettes which have a labeled central bulb. For 10 points each:
answer: volumetric [accept volumetric pipettes or volumetric flasks; prompt on graduated]
the tip [accept pipette tips; prompt on the end; do not accept or prompt on “stem”]
parts: Give this adjective, also used for a type of long-necked flask with a pear-shaped body. Glassware with this designation typically has a single gradation which has been precisely calibrated.
A major use case of volumetric flasks is producing solutions with accurate values of this quantity measured in molarity.

This part of any volumetric glassware should only be cleaned after measurements are completed, as the liquid retained there is included in calibration. The micropipettes common in biochemistry come without this part.

bonuses.leadin: This man ordered the construction of a pontoon bridge over the Hellespont during one military campaign. For 10 points each:
answer: Mount Athos [prompt on Agion Oros or Holy Mountain]
parts: Identify this Persian ruler and successor of Darius I whose forces were eventually victorious at the Battle of Thermopylae.

Plutarch relates how some workers had their ears and noses mutilated while attempting to dig a canal through this mountain on orders of Xerxes. In the 20th century, the Greek Constitution granted autonomy to a Monastic Republic on this mountain.
Xerxes's commander Mardonius died in this final decisive land battle in the second Persian invasion of Greece. This battle was fought on the slopes of Mount Cithaeron.

bonuses.leadin: This man’s house can be seen in a sketch titled The Mill Stream, which depicts a water wheel on a side stream of the river Stour. For 10 points each:
answer: a cathedral [or Salisbury Cathedral or Cathedral Church of the Blessed Virgin Mary; prompt on “church”]
parts: Identify this tenant farmer who lived near Flatford Mill in Dedham Vale for upwards of 80 years. His cottage is most prominently depicted in The Hay Wain.
This British landscape artist painted The Hay Wain. This artist was often compared to his contemporary J.M.W. Turner.

A critic in The Gentleman's Magazine attacked Constable for seeming to have depicted one of these buildings "immediately after a snow storm." Constable painted one of these buildings "from the Meadows."

bonuses.leadin: Title V of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure allows plaintiffs to use this process to build a case even if they lack solid evidence. For 10 points each:
answer: Maryland (the case is Barron v. Baltimore)
parts: Identify this pre-trial phase in civil suits where parties exchange info. Its name implies parties are finding evidence.
A subpoena duces tecum collects evidence for discovery. Other subpoenas compel the testimony of these people, who are sometimes put into namesake protection programs.

Evidence gathered during discovery is governed by the Brady decision, a case from this state. The Court ruled the Bill of Rights didn't apply to the states in an 1833 case involving a silted-over wharf in this state's largest city.

bonuses.leadin: During World War II, the remnants of this organization were housed at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton. For 10 points each:
answer: The League of Nations [or Société des Nations]
Vilnius [or Wilno; or Wilna; or Vilna; or Vilno; or Vina; or Vinyus]
Syria [or Syrian Arab Republic; or Syrie] (the ophthalmologist is Bashar al-Assad)
parts: Identify this international organization, the predecessor to the UN.

Before a League of Nations-supervised plebiscite could take place in this so-called "Jerusalem of the North," it was annexed by Poland. The January Events in this capital city were part of the 1991 Singing Revolution against the Soviets.

Class A mandates supervised by the League of Nations included a French one named for this modern-day country. The Alawite ophthalmologist who now rules this country has struggled to regain control of Rojava ("roe-jah-vuh") in a bloody war.

bonuses.leadin: This writer "corrected" a student's literal translation of the phrase "I love you" by suggesting the meaning of the English phrase is captured better by "the moon is beautiful." For 10 points each:
answer: Natsume Soseki [accept names in either order; accept Natsume Kin'nosuke or Natsume Sōseki; or Soseki Natsume]
Kafka on the Shore [or Umibe no Kafuka]
parts: Name this author. One of his protagonists observes the scientist Avalon Coldmoon and the professor Mr. Sneaze, the latter of whom is also referred to as "my master."
Soseki's novel I am a Cat was written with this Western technique, in which the story is told through the narrator's uninterrupted thoughts.
Nakata talks to cats throughout this Haruki Murakami novel. Its protagonist reads Soseki while hiding in a library and adopts the name of another favorite writer.

bonuses.leadin: The Bauyn (“BAU-in”) Manuscript contains 122 pieces by a member of this family credited with the invention of the unmeasured prelude. For 10 points each:
answer: Couperin [Louis Couperin and Francois Couperin "Le grand"]
parts: That composer, whose first name was Louis, was a member of what musical family? Another composer in this family included eight measured preludes in his treatise on The Art of Playing a certain instrument.
That Francois Couperin treatise concerned this Baroque keyboard instrument later played by Wanda Landowska. A plectrum plucks a string when a key on this instrument is pressed.

This "Isaac Newton of music" theorized a "fundamental bass" key to Western art music in his Treatise on Harmony. This Frenchman's operas include Les indes galantes (“LEZ AHND guh-LOHNT”) and Hippolyte et Aricie (“EE-poh-LEET ay AH-ree-SEE”).

bonuses.leadin: In a novel from this country, Erika Kohut takes large instruments onto trains so that she can hit people with them. For 10 points each:
answer: Austria [or Republic of Austria; or Republik Österreich]
Roth [or Joseph Roth; or Philip Roth]
parts: Name this home country of the author of The Piano Teacher, Elfriede Jelinek. A pianist commits suicide after noting he will never be as good as Glenn Gould in a novel set in this country's city of Salzburg.
A newly published digital edition of this other Austrian author's unfinished magnum opus, The Man Without Qualities, exceeds 11,000 pages in length.
An Austrian author with this surname discussed three generations of the Trotta family in Radetzky March. An American author with this surname created the character of Nathan Zuckerman.

bonuses.leadin: Different areas of physics have different natural mathematical "languages." Answer some things about them, for 10 points each.
answer: calculus [accept vector calculus or real analysis]
linear algebra [prompt on algebra; prompt on abstract algebra]
Kingdom of Norway [accept Kongeriket Noreg] (Those mathematicians are Sophus Lie and Niels Henrik Abel)
parts: The "vector" form of this area of math is the language of classical electromagnetism. This area of math is concerned with evaluating derivatives and integrals.
The bra-ket notation of quantum mechanics has its foundations in this area of math. This area of math deals with matrices and systems of equations.

Particle physicists make heavy use of the representation theory of groups and algebras discovered by a mathematician from this country. Commutative groups are named after another mathematician from this country.

bonuses.leadin: This man nearly sold a collection including sixteen metopes (“MEH-toe-pays”) of battles between centaurs and Lapiths to Prince Ludwig of Bavaria. For 10 points each:
answer: Lord Elgin [or Thomas Bruce, Seventh Earl of Elgin]
Hobby Lobby [or Hobby Lobby Stores Inc. or Hobby Lobby Creative Centers]
parts: Identify this British nobleman whose namesake marbles were taken from Athens' Parthenon and are now in the British Museum.

The US government sued this company in 2017 over its smuggling of thousands of clay tablets intended for its founder's Museum of the Bible. This company's founders are currently suing Christie's over the sale of the stolen Gilgamesh Dream Tablet.
Those tablets were plundered from this country. The Islamic State destroyed many mosques in this country's city of Mosul.
